newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Swedish Sodra says no $620 pulp before January.
newsitem.headline: Swedish Sodra says no $620 pulp before January.

text.p: Swedish forestry group Sodra on Thursday said pulp prices could not be raised to $620 a tonne until January next year at the earliest.
"I do not think we can see this announced price of $620 during the (fourth) quarter. It possibly could become reality in January," Sodra Cell's marketing director Hans Burmeister told Reuters.
Burmeister said stocks of long-fibre pulp in NorScan countries except Sweden rose by 23,000 tonnes in October.

"The inventories increased by 23,000 if Sweden is not included... my feeling is that the Swedish stocks were at worst unchanged," added Burmeister, quoting figures from sector organisations in the other countries.
Burmeister said there had been expectations of a substantial increase in the October pulp inventories.
The marketing director, talking to Reuters in Stockholm from a forestry industry conference in London, described the atmosphere there as cautiously optimistic.
"This whole week we have seen there is a budding optimism in the sector. I hope this means better conditions for raising prices but in the short-term it may not be so easy," he said.
